Term.definition: Removes the first element from an array and returns it, shifting remaining elements left.
A Mocha test function that marks a test as skipped and does not run it.
A lightweight, standalone executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software.
External libraries or packages required for a program or project to function correctly.
A communication endpoint for network connections, identified by a number, used to route traffic.
Event handler in React triggered when the value of an input element changes.
Web API for storing key-value pairs in a user's browser persistently.
A function that processes events or requests, such as HTTP requests, in a program.
A text-based interface for entering commands and interacting with the operating system.
External libraries or modules required for a project to work correctly.
Integrated Development Environment; software for writing, testing, and debugging code.
A protocol enabling real-time, two-way communication between client and server over a single connection.
A set of rules allowing programs to interact and exchange data with each other.
A string used to verify user identity in authentication systems, often encoded and signed.
Key-value pairs sent with HTTP requests or responses, providing metadata such as authentication information.
The data contained within a token, often user information or claims.
A numeric code in HTTP responses indicating the result of a request, e.g., 401 for unauthorized.
A function that processes HTTP requests for a specific route in a web server.
A set of rules for interacting with web services using HTTP methods like GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
Digital keys used to verify a user's identity when accessing protected resources or APIs.
A text file with instructions to build a Docker image for an application.
Files generated as output from the build process, ready for deployment or distribution.
A starting point Docker image used to build new images by adding layers on top.
A lightweight, isolated environment to run applications, using the host OS kernel.
The live environment where applications are deployed for end-users, as opposed to development or testing.
The server-side part of an application, handling data processing, storage, and business logic.
The client-side part of an application, responsible for user interface and user experience.
External libraries or packages that an application requires to function properly.
A selectable item in a hierarchy, often representing a resource or component in a UI.
A shared boundary or contract for how different components interact or communicate in software.
A specific URL pattern handled by a server, mapping requests to code logic.
A file containing code to automatically verify that software behaves as expected.
The process of responding to and managing errors in a program's execution.
A numeric value indicating the result of an operation, often used in HTTP responses.
Development involving both frontend (client-side) and backend (server-side) parts of an application.
Common abbreviation for JavaScript, a popular programming language for web development.
A syntax extension for JavaScript, commonly used with React to describe UI elements.
A function in testing frameworks to group related test cases together.
A function in testing frameworks to define an individual test case.
A function that processes requests between the client and server, often used for tasks like authentication or logging.
An object that defines and groups route handlers for specific URL paths in a web application.
A numeric code in HTTP responses indicating the result of a request, like 200 for success or 404 for not found.
A password transformed into a fixed-length string using a cryptographic hash function for secure storage.
A middleware that enables cross-origin requests between different domains in web applications.
Express middleware that parses incoming JSON request bodies and populates req.body.
A logging middleware for Express that records HTTP requests and responses.
An architecture where applications are built from independent, reusable pieces called components.
A programming style where you describe what should happen, not how to do it.
A tool that automates compiling, bundling, and optimizing source code for deployment.
A local server that automatically reloads and serves your app during development.
An architectural style for designing networked APIs using HTTP methods like GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE.
A URL pattern and handler in a web server that processes specific HTTP requests.
A text-based interface for interacting with the operating system or running commands.
A numerical identifier for a specific process or service on a computer network.
A package or library that a project requires to function properly.
A function that processes incoming requests and generates responses in a web application.
A URL pattern that determines how requests are handled in a web server.
A programming technique where multiple methods are called sequentially on the same object.
A function that processes requests between receiving them and sending responses, often used for tasks like authentication.
A React hook for running side effects in function components, such as data fetching or subscriptions.
A web storage API that allows saving key-value pairs in a user's browser persistently.
A method used to send events and data to the server or other clients via WebSockets.
A protocol enabling real-time, two-way communication between client and server over a single persistent connection.
To send or trigger an event, often with data, in event-driven programming.
A way to hide complex details, exposing only necessary functionality to other parts of the program.
A shared boundary for communication between software components, defining accessible methods or properties.
A text file with instructions to build a Docker image for your application.
A tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications using a YAML file.
A web browser API for storing key-value pairs locally on the user's device.
A React hook that runs side effects after component render or update.
The server-side part of an application handling data processing and logic, not visible to users.
A URL pattern that the server listens to and responds with specific content or actions.
A number sent by a server to indicate the result of an HTTP request.
Process of verifying user identity to grant access to specific features or data.
The process of creating applications that run in a web browser.
A function that processes requests between the client and server, often used for authentication or logging.
The data contained within a token, often holding user information or claims.
The initial connection process between a client and server in socket communication.
A method to register middleware functions for all socket connections in a Socket.IO server.
A number indicating the result of an HTTP request, like 200 for success or 400 for error.
A MIME type indicating the HTTP response body contains JSON-formatted data.
Configuration file for Vite, a build tool for modern web projects.
A Node.js library for testing HTTP servers by making requests and asserting responses.
A Jest hook that runs a function once after all tests in a file complete.
A Jest hook that runs a function once before all tests in a file start.
A Jest function for grouping related tests into a test suite.
A Jest function that defines an individual test case.
A specific URL path where an API receives requests and sends responses.
External libraries or modules required for a project to work.
Jest configuration option specifying the environment in which tests run, e.g., 'node' or 'jsdom'.
Jest configuration option for specifying which files are considered test files.
A Node.js tool to execute binaries from npm packages without installing them globally.
A property passed to a React component to configure its behavior or data.
A function passed as an argument to be executed later, often after an event.
A reusable, self-contained piece of UI in React applications.
An object or value that determines a componentâ€™s behavior and rendering in React.
The process of generating and displaying UI elements on the screen.
A function passed as an argument to another function, to be called later.
The part of a web application that users interact with directly in their browser.
The server-side part of an application, handling logic, data storage, and security.
A reusable, self-contained piece of UI in frameworks like React.
A function designed to handle specific events, such as clicks or form submissions.
The process of defining how URLs map to components or pages in a web application.
Application Programming Interface; a set of rules for interacting with software components.
A popular JavaScript library for making HTTP requests from the browser or Node.js.
A protocol enabling two-way communication between client and server over a single, long-lived connection.
A JavaScript library for real-time, bidirectional communication between web clients and servers.
Repeatedly requesting data from a server at regular intervals to check for updates.
A minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework for building APIs and web servers.
A Node.js built-in module for creating HTTP servers and handling HTTP requests.
A fast build tool and development server for modern web projects, especially with frameworks like React.
A tool to run multiple commands or scripts simultaneously in a single terminal window.
The server-side part of an application, handling data processing and business logic.
A defined structure specifying methods and properties for objects to implement in code.
A technique to hide complex implementation details, exposing only essential features.
A fast build tool and development server for modern web projects, especially with frameworks like React.
A syntax extension for JavaScript that allows writing HTML-like code in React components.
A set of rules for interacting with software components or web services.
Functions in Express.js that process requests before reaching route handlers.
Standardized code used as a starting point for new projects.
A column or field that uniquely identifies each record in a database table.
A Sequelize method to find a record by its primary key.
A Sequelize method to retrieve all records that match given criteria.
A Sequelize method used to delete records from a database table.
The part of a web application that users interact with directly in their browsers.
A popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces, especially single-page applications.
The process of determining which page or component to display based on the URL.
An object that stores dynamic data and determines a component's behavior in React.
Web services that follow REST principles, allowing communication between client and server using HTTP methods.
Small pieces of data used for authentication and authorization in web applications.
A function in Express that processes requests before they reach the route handler.
A password transformed into a fixed-length string using a cryptographic hash function for security.
A React Hook that lets you add state to functional components.
A React Hook for running side effects in functional components after render.
A browser API for storing key-value data persistently on the client side.
A popular JavaScript library for making HTTP requests from the browser or Node.js.
A function that processes requests between the client and server, often used for logging or authentication.
External libraries or modules that a project requires to function correctly.
A file in Node.js projects that manages metadata and dependencies for the application.
The part of a web application that users interact with directly in their browser.
The server-side part of an application handling logic, database, and client requests.
A React Hook that lets you add state variables to functional components.
A web browser API for storing key-value data locally, persisting across sessions.
An HTTP request method used to send data to a server to create or update resources.
A JavaScript library for making HTTP requests from the browser or Node.js.
A protocol enabling two-way, real-time communication between client and server over a single connection.
A text file with instructions to build a Docker image for your application.
A YAML file defining how to run multi-container Docker applications together.
A file containing environment variables, often used to manage configuration and secrets.
A storage location for code, often managed with version control systems like Git.
A web service that uses HTTP requests for communication, following REST architectural principles.
Exchanging data instantly between client and server, often using technologies like WebSockets.
Data stored temporarily in RAM, lost when the application stops or restarts.
The part of an application responsible for managing and accessing data sources.
The data sent with an event or request, often containing relevant information for processing.
Sending a message to all connected clients simultaneously in a networked application.
A protocol enabling two-way, real-time communication between client and server over a single persistent connection.
URL patterns in a web application that determine how requests are handled by the backend.
The process of verifying what actions or resources a user is allowed to access.
A function that processes requests before they reach the main route handler in web applications.
Functions that process HTTP requests for specific paths in a web server.
React Hook for adding state to functional components.
Event handler in React triggered when a form field's value changes.
JavaScript keyword used to wait for a Promise to resolve in async functions.
HTTP method for sending data to a server, often used for creating resources.
JavaScript object type that stores key-value pairs and remembers the original insertion order.
An object in Express.js used to define a group of related routes.
Functions that process incoming HTTP requests for specific routes in web frameworks.
A statement used to include modules or files in JavaScript or Node.js.
Express.js method to mount middleware or routers at a specified path.
Express.js method to send a JSON response to the client.
An object containing data sent by the client in the body of an HTTP request.
Express.js method to set the HTTP status code for the response.
URL patterns that determine how requests are handled by a server or web application.
Recording information about a programâ€™s execution, often for debugging or monitoring purposes.
Messages sent by clients to servers to ask for data or perform actions.
Messages sent from a server to a client, usually as a reply to a request.
Integrated Development Environments; software applications that provide tools for coding, debugging, and testing.
A set of rules for communication between software components or systems.
Specific URLs on a server where API requests are sent to access resources or services.
A system where each request is independent and does not rely on previous interactions.
A collection of tools and libraries that simplifies software development for specific tasks.
Software that executes code and provides necessary services for running programs.
JSON Web Token, a compact way to securely transmit information between parties as a JSON object.
Initial connection process in Socket.IO, where authentication and setup information are exchanged.
A platform that executes code, providing necessary resources and services for programs to run.
The part of an application that users interact with directly in their browser.
Code that runs on a server, handling requests and processing data before sending responses to clients.
A collection of libraries and tools that can be integrated into projects to extend functionality.
A programming paradigm where flow is determined by events like user actions or messages.
A method of programming where tasks run independently without blocking the main execution flow.
A compact, URL-safe token format used for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.
A built-in Node.js module providing cryptographic functionality such as encryption, decryption, and secure random number generation.
A storage location for code, typically managed with version control systems like Git.
A file in Node.js projects that defines metadata, dependencies, and scripts for the project.
A syntax extension for JavaScript that allows mixing HTML-like code with JavaScript logic.
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces using components and state.
A special function in React that lets you use state and other features in functional components.
An object or value that determines a component's behavior and how it renders.
An event handler attribute in React triggered when input field values change.
A URL pattern the server listens to, triggering specific handler code when matched.
A function that processes incoming requests for a specific route in a web server.
A numeric code in HTTP responses indicating the result of a request, like 200 or 400.
Key-value pairs in a URL after '?', used to pass data to the server.
An object in React that stores dynamic data and determines component rendering.
An event handler in React triggered when the value of an input element changes.
A property in React input elements that sets or reflects the current input content.
The process of verifying a user's identity before granting access to resources.
Web apps that load a single HTML page and dynamically update content without full page reloads.
The server-side part of an application, handling data storage, logic, and communication with databases.
A text file with instructions to build a Docker image for a containerized application.
A lightweight, isolated environment for running applications, created and managed by containerization platforms like Docker.
A packaged snapshot of an application and its dependencies, used to create containers.
Key-value pairs used to configure applications at runtime without changing code.
Storage that retains data even after the container is stopped or removed.
A private network for containers to communicate securely within the same Docker environment.
